document.docAuthor: Bifi, Alessandro Gasparetto & Pavanelli, Carla Simone & Zawadzki, Cláudio Henrique
document.docTitle: Three new species of Ancistrus Kner, 1854 (Siluriformes: Loricariidae) from the Rio Iguaçu basin, Paraná State, Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of Ancistrus Kner, 1854 (Siluriformes: Loricariidae) from the Rio Iguaçu basin, Paraná State, Brazil

docTitle.emphasis:
Three new species of
Ancistrus Kner, 1854
( Siluriformes : Loricariidae ) from the Rio Iguaçu basin, Paraná State, Brazil

subSection.paragraph: ALESSANDRO GASPARETTO BIFI 1 , CARLA SIMONE PAVANELLI1, 2
& CLÁUDIO HENRIQUE ZAWADZKI 2

paragraph.emphasis: Universidade Estadual de Maringá, Programa de Pós-Graduação em Ecologia de Ambientes Aquáticos Continentais (PEA), Av. Colombo, 5790, 87020- 900 Maringá, Paraná, Brazil . E-mail: agbifi@hotmail.com, carlasp@nupelia.uem.br
Universidade Estadual de Maringá, Núcleo de Pesquisas em Limnologia, Ictiologia e Aqüicultura (Nupélia), Av. Colombo, 5790, 87020- 900 Maringá, Paraná, Brazil . E-mail: chzawadzki@nupelia.uem.br

subSection.paragraph:
The Rio Iguaçu basin, a tributary to the left bank of the Rio Paraná, is characterized by high endemism of fish species. Several specimens of
Ancistrus
, family Loricariidae , were recently caught in that river and they were attributed to three new species that are described herein. They can be diagnosed from their congeners by having short maxillary barbels which are not free from the lower lip, by lacking pre-anal fin plate and also by morphometric and meristic traits. Comments on the geographic distribution of those species and congeners are also provided, in addition to a key to the species from the Río de La Plata and coastal basins from southern Brazil .
Key words : Ancistrini , armored catfish, endemism, Neotropical fishes, taxonomy

A bacia do rio Iguaçu, um tributário da margem esquerda do rio Paraná, é caracterizada por um elevado endemismo de peixes. Muitos espécimes de
Ancistrus
, família Loricariidae , foram recentemente capturados neste rio e foram atribuídos a três espécies novas que são descritas aqui. Elas podem ser diagnosticadas de suas congêneres por apresentarem o barbilhão maxilar curto e aderido ao lábio inferior, por não apresentarem placa pré-nadadeira anal e ainda por caracteres morfométricos e merísticos. Comentários sobre a distribuição geográfica dessas espécies e de congêneres são igualmente fornecidos, assim como uma chave para as espécies das bacias do rio da Prata e costeiras do sul do Brasil .

Ancistrus Kner, 1854
is an armored catfish genus widespread in the Neotropical region, from Panama to Río de La Plata in Argentina . It currently includes 59 valid species, since
A. mattogrossensis Miranda-Ribeiro, 1912
has been excluded, probably due to its uncertain type-locality, misleading original description, and missing type-material (
Ferraris Jr., 2007
). According to
Fisch-Muller ( 2003 )
, seven species of
Ancistrus
have been described and are valid from the Río de La Plata drainage:
A. cirrhosus (Valenciennes, 1840 )
,
A. claro
Knaack, 1999
,
A. cuiabae
Knaack, 1999
,
A. formoso Sabino & Trajano, 1997
,
A. pirareta Muller, 1989
,
A. piriformis Muller, 1989
and
A. taunayi Miranda-Ribeiro, 1918
. Species of
Ancistrus
can be diagnosed from other Loricariidae by lacking plates and odontodes on the anterior margin of the snout, where there are only fleshy tentacles, in addition to well-developed interopercular spines.

Abell et al. ( 2008 )
classified the Rio Iguaçu basin as an ecoregion that presents few fish species, but with 51 to 71 % of endemic species. The Rio Iguaçu flows through the three Paranean plateaus, which delimitate the upper, middle and lower Rio Iguaçu sections. The region of the upper Rio Iguaçu is separated from the middle Rio Iguaçu by the Salto Caiacanga, and the middle Rio Iguaçu was separated from the lower Rio Iguaçu by the Salto Grande (
Ingenito et al. 2004
), which is currently flooded by the Foz do Areia Reservoir.

In field-work carried out by the Núcleo de Pesquisas em Limnologia, Ictiologia e Aquicultura (Nupélia), in addition to some further lots from other museums, specimens of the genus
Ancistrus
apparently belonging to new species were found along the entire Rio Iguaçu basin. This work describes these three new
Ancistrus
species, the only genus representative of the tribe Ancistrini in that basin.

Measurements were taken using a digital caliper to the nearest 0.01 mm , and are presented as percentages of standard length (SL), head length (HL), caudal-peduncle length, anal to caudal-fin length, and interorbital distance. Counts were taken using stereomicroscope. Methodology follows that proposed by
Fisch-Muller et al. ( 2001 )
, with addition of subsequent measurements and counts: prepectoral length (from tip of snout to origin of pectoral-fin spine); prepelvic length (from tip of snout to origin of pelvic-fin spine); adipose- to caudal-fin distance (from origin of adipose-fin spine to last dorsal plate); anal- to caudal-fin distance (from origin of unbranched anal-fin ray to last ventral plate); number of procurrent plates. Nomenclature of lateral plate series follows
Schaefer ( 1997 )
.

Morphometric features, excluding length of caudal-fin spine and interbranchial distance, were used for size-free canonical discriminant analysis ( CDA ), following procedures proposed by
Reis et al. ( 1990 )
, using the software SAS ® ( Statistical Analysis System ). For that, in case of missing some measurement, it was estimated using a simple linear regression with SL. Considering percents and counts no sexual dimorphism was apparent, and therefore this source of variation was not considered.

Institutional abbreviations follow
Leviton et al. ( 1985 )
, with addition of MHNCI (Museu de História Natural do Capão de Imbuia, Curitiba), MUSM (Museo de Historia Natural, Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos, Lima) and NUP (Coleção Ictiológica do Nupélia - Núcleo de Pesquisas em Limnologia, Ictiologia e Aquicultura, Universidade Estadual de Maringá, Maringá). In the collector section of listed material, Copel (Companhia Paranaense de Energia), and Nupélia mean the staff of ichthyologic collectors of each institution.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Ancistrus abilhoai
, MZUSP 104116, holotype, 99.3 mm SL; Brazil, Paraná, Lapa, upper Rio Iguaçu basin, affluent of Rio Iguaçu.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Ancistrus abilhoai
is diagnosed from congeners inhabiting the Río de La Plata and coastal basins of southern Brazil , except
A. agostinhoi
,
A. formoso
,
A. multispinis
,
A. mullerae
and
A. taunayi ,
by having maxillary barbel shorter and not free from lower lip ( vs. longer and free from lower lip); from
A. agostinhoi
,
A. multispinis
,
A. mullerae
and
A. taunayi
by width of mandibulary teeth row ( 13.4–15.5 % of HL vs. 15.8–19.3 %, 15.5–19.4 %, 16.5 –21.0% and 15.8–23.1 %, respectively, and 32.9–37.9 % of interorbital width vs. 38.4–53.6 %, 40.7–53.8 %, 39.3 –58.0% and 39.4–51.4 %, respectively); from
A. formoso
by orbital diameter ( 11.9–15.3 % of HL vs. 8.3–8.7 %), caudal peduncle depth (9.0– 10.9 % of SL vs. 7.8–8.7 %) and number of dentary teeth ( 40–68 vs. 110 ).

Description. Morphometric data presented in
Table 1
and counts in
Table 4
. Head and body depressed. Dorsal profile of head and trunk convex from tip of snout to supraoccipital, then slightly convex to adipose fin and slightly concave to end of caudal peduncle. Ventral profile of body straight, slightly concave on ventral portion of caudal peduncle; caudal peduncle elliptical and short, 26.2–30.5 % of SL.

Snout rounded in dorsal view, with naked margin bordered by dermic platelets of variable lengths on its lateral portion; naked area larger in males. Adult males with small- to middle-sized tentacles, unbranched on dorsal region of snout and aligned small tentacles along snout border. Females usually with two very small tentacles on each side of snout border.

Eye middle-sized, with slightly raised dorsal margin. Interorbital region slightly concave. Exposed portion of opercle usually somewhat triangular, rounded anteriorly; postopercular region with few platelets near to pterotic-supracleithrum, naked on its anterior portion.

Dorsal-fin origin situated slightly anterior to vertical through pelvic-fin origin; dorsal fin when adpressed usually not reaching preadipose plate; dorsal-fin spine short. Adipose-fin spine short, slightly curved inward. Pectoral-fin spine with odontodes hypertrophied and tentacles on its distal portion; pectoral-fin length variable, usually surpassing a half length of adpressed pelvic fin. Depressed pelvic-fin spine surpassing origin of anal fin. Anal fin short. Caudal-fin margin slightly concave; lowermost spine slightly longer than superior. Fin-ray formulae: dorsal
I 7
; pectoral
I 6
; pelvic
I 5
; anal
I 3–4
; caudal
I 14
I.

Sexual dimorphism. Males are usually larger than females; largest male and female with 106.2 mm and 84.9 mm SL, respectively. Mature males have small- to middle-sized tentacles on dorsal region and border of snout. Females can have few shorter tentacles, usually two on each side of snout.

Color in alcohol. Background color brown; light-brown, irregular, small dots over body, middle-sized on head and trunk, and smaller on snout, more defined over head. Lips yellowish. Ventral region of body brownish to anal fin, with diffuse, pale, round dots or vermiculations. Fins yellowish, with dark-brown dots forming three or four stripes or greater round blotches. Sometimes this color pattern can happen in reverse.

Etymology. The species name,
abilhoai
, is in honor of Vinícius Abilhoa, who has collected some specimens that served as the basis for the species description, and who has been of great assistance to the authors in this and other studies as curator of the Collection of Fishes of the Museu de História Natural do Capão de Imbuia ( MHNCI ) in Curitiba. A patronym.

Distribution.
Ancistrus abilhoai
is more commonly found in upper and middle Rio Iguaçu basin, Southern Brazil , and one single lot at lower Rio Iguaçu (
Fig. 3
). Additional comments are provided in the discussion.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Geographic distribution and type-localities of
Ancistrus abilhoai
(dot, square= type-locality),
Ancistrus agostinhoi
(diamond, asterisk= type-locality) and
Ancistrus mullerae
(triangle, star= type-locality). Salto Caiacanga (1) and Salto Grande (2) split upper, middle and lower Rio Iguaçu basin. Foz do Areia dam (A), Salto Segredo dam (B) and Salto Caxias dam (C).

TABLE 1. Morphometric data for
Ancistrus abilhoai
. SD= standard deviation, N= number of observations (including the holotype).

Diagnosis.
Ancistrus agostinhoi
is diagnosed from congeners inhabiting the Río de La Plata and coastal basins of southern Brazil , except
A. abilhoai
,
A. formoso
,
A. mullerae
,
A. multispinis
and
A. taunayi
by having maxillary barbel shorter and not free from lower lip ( vs. longer and free from lower lip); from
A. abilhoai
by width of mandibulary teeth row ( 15.8–19.3 % of HL vs. 13.4–15.5 % and 38.4–53.6 % of interorbital width vs. 32.9–37.9 %); from
A. formoso
by orbital diameter ( 12.3–17.3 % of HL vs. 8.3–8.7 %), caudal peduncle depth ( 10.6 –12.0% of SL vs. 7.8–8.7 %) and number of dentary teeth ( 38–78 vs. 110 ); from
A. multispinis
and
A. taunayi
by occipital depth ( 18.8 –22.0% of SL vs. 16.2 –18.0% and 17.3–17.9 %, respectively); from
A. mullerae
by occipital depth ( 18.8 –22.0% of SL vs. 15.4–18.8 %) and head length ( 37.8–41.4 % of SL, mean= 38.9 % vs. 34.4–37.9 %, mean= 36.3 %).

Description. Morphometric data presented in Table 2 and counts in
Table 4
. Head and body depressed. Dorsal profile of head and trunk convex from tip of snout to supraoccipital, then slightly convex to adipose fin and concave to end of caudal peduncle. Ventral profile of body straight, slightly concave on ventral portion of caudal peduncle; caudal peduncle elliptical, tall and short, 24.3–29.4 % of SL.

Snout rounded in dorsal view, with naked margin bordered by dermic platelets of variable lengths on its lateral portion; naked area larger in males. Adult males with small- to middle-sized tentacles, unbranched on dorsal region of snout and aligned small tentacles along snout border. Females usually with two very small tentacles on each side of snout border.

Eye small to middle-sized, with slightly raised dorsal margin. Interorbital region slightly concave. Exposed portion of opercle usually somewhat triangular, rounded anteriorly; post-opercular region with few platelets near to pterotic-supracleithrum, naked on its anterior portion.

Supraoccipital with margins between surrounding bones and plates not clearly visible; delimited posteriorly by first line of predorsal plates. Five lateral series of plates, three lateral series on the narrower portion of caudal peduncle. Mid-dorsal and mid-ventral series not surpassing adipose fin. Short odontodes present on fin rays, and body plates. Abdomen entirely devoid of plates. Base of first anal-fin pterygiophore covered by skin (without externally preanal platelet-like element).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Ancistrus agostinhoi
, MZUSP 104118, holotype, 96.1 mm SL; Brazil, Paraná, lower Rio Iguaçu basin, Rio Jordão, affluent of Rio Iguaçu.

tr.th:
TABLE 2. Morphometric data for
Ancistrus
the holotype).
Adipose fin to caudal fin distance
Anal fin to caudal fin distance
Percents of anal to caudal fin distance
Adipose fin to caudal fin distance

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dorsal-fin origin situated slightly anterior to vertical through pelvic-fin origin; dorsal fin when adpressed usually reaching preadipose plate; dorsal-fin spine short. Adipose-fin spine short, slightly curved inward. Pectoral-fin spine with odontodes hypertrophied and tentacles on its distal portion; pectoral-fin length variable, usually surpassing a half length of adpressed pelvic fin. Depressed pelvic-fin spine surpassing origin of anal fin. Anal fin short. Caudal-fin margin obliquely truncate; lowermost spine slightly longer than superior. Fin-ray formulae: dorsal
I 7
(one specimen presenting
I 8
, lot NUP 4061 ); pectoral
I 6
; pelvic
I 5
; anal
I 3–4
; caudal
I 14
I.

Sexual dimorphism. Males are usually larger than females; largest male and female with 96.1 mm and 76.3 mm SL, respectively. Mature males have small- to middle-sized tentacles on dorsal region and border of snout. Females can have few shorter tentacles, usually two on each side of snout.

Color in alcohol. Background color dark-gray; usually with light-brown, irregular, small dots over body, more defined over head. Lips yellowish. Ventral region of body dark-gray to anal fin, with diffuse, lightbrown, round dots or vermiculations. Fins yellowish, with dark-gray dots forming three to five stripes on even fins, and four or five on odd fins.

Etymology. The species name,
agostinhoi
, is in honor of Ângelo Antônio Agostinho, in recognition of his myriad contributions to our knowledge of ecology of Neotropical fishes, and his great participation in the establishment of the Núcleo de Pesquisas em Limnologia, Ictiologia e Aquicultura, Nupélia, one of the most important centers of research in ecology of fishes of the Latin America . A patronym.

Distribution.
Ancistrus agostinhoi
is only known from the Rio Jordão drainage, affluent of lower Rio Iguaçu, Southern Brazil (
Fig. 3
).

Anal fin to caudal fin distance
Percents of anal to caudal fin distance
Adipose fin to caudal fin distance

subSubSection.paragraph:
continued next page
A. abilhoai A. agostinhoi A. mullerae

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 4. Meristic data for
Ancistrus abilhoai
(N=18),
Ancistrus agostinhoi
(N=48) and
Ancistrus mullerae
(N=80) from the Rio Iguaçu basin. SD= standard length.

subSubSection.paragraph: Characters range mean ± SD range mean ± SD range mean ± SD Dermal plates

Upper procurrents 5–6 5.8 ± 0.4 4–6 5.0± 0.3 5–6 5.1 ± 0.3 Lower procurrents 4 4.0±0.0 3–4 3.6 ± 0.5 3–4 3.8 ± 0.4 Dentary teeth 40–68 49.9 ± 8.6 38–78 53.9 ± 7.8 51–97 71.9 ± 10.7 Premaxillary teeth 41–64 49.1 ± 7.6 36–74 51.0± 7.9 45–88 69.0± 10.1 Interopercular spines 18–25 21.3 ± 2.3 15–23 19.0± 2.4 12–22 17.0± 2.5 Diagnosis.
Ancistrus mullerae
is diagnosed from congeners inhabiting the Río de La Plata and coastal basins of southern Brazil , except
A. abilhoai
,
A. agostinhoi
,
A. formoso
,
A. multispinis
and
A. taunayi ,
by having maxillary barbel short and not free from lower lip ( vs. longer and free from lower lip); from
A. abilhoai
by width of mandibulary teeth row ( 16.5 –21.0% of HL vs. 13.4–15.5 % and 39.3 –58.0% of interorbital width vs. 32.9–37.9 %); from
A. agostinhoi
by occipital depth ( 15.4–18.8 % of SL vs. 18.8 –22.0%) and head length ( 34.4–37.9 %, mean= 36.3 % of SL vs. 37.8–41.4 %, mean= 38.9 %); from
A. formoso
by orbital diameter ( 11.9–18.4 % of HL vs. 8.3–8.7 %), caudal peduncle depth ( 8.8–11.5 % of SL vs. 7.8–8.7 %) and number of dentary teeth ( 51–97 vs. 110 ); from
A. multispinis
and
A. taunayi
by number of interopercular spines ( 12–22 vs. 24–35 and 22–28 , respectively).

Description. Morphometric data presented in
Table 3
and counts in
Table 4
. Head and body fairly depressed. Dorsal profile of head and trunk slightly convex from tip of snout to supraoccipital, then slightly convex to adipose fin and slightly concave to end of caudal peduncle. Ventral profile of body straight, slightly concave on ventral portion of caudal peduncle; caudal peduncle elliptical and relatively short, 25.1–32.8 % of SL.

Snout rounded in dorsal view, with naked margin bordered by dermic platelets of variable lengths on its lateral portion, naked area larger in males. Adult males with middle- to large-sized tentacles, sometimes a few branched on dorsal region of snout and anterior most tentacles aligned along anterior margin of snout. Females usually with two very small tentacles on each side of snout border.

Eye middle-sized, with a little raised dorsal margin. Interorbital region slightly concave. Exposed portion of opercle usually somewhat triangular, rounded anteriorly; postopercular region with few platelets near to pterotic-supracleithrum, sometimes with a few platelets on its anterior portion.

tr.th: TABLE 5. Coefficients of size-free discriminant Rio Iguaçu basin.

analisys for
Ancistrus
abilhoai ,
A. agostinhoi
and
Adipose fin to caudal fin distance
Anal fin to caudal fin distance

subSubSection.paragraph: Supraoccipital with margins between surrounding bones and plates not clearly visible; delimited posteriorly by first line of predorsal plates. Five lateral series of plates, three lateral series on the narrower portion of caudal peduncle. Mid-dorsal and mid-ventral series not surpassing adipose fin. Short odontodes present on fin rays, and body plates. Abdomen entirely devoid of plates. Base of first anal-fin pterygiophore covered by skin (without externally preanal platelet-like element).

Dorsal-fin origin situated slightly anterior to vertical through pelvic-fin origin; dorsal fin when adpressed almost reaching, or, in larger specimens, surpassing a little preadipose plate. Adipose-fin spine short, slightly curved inward. Pectoral-fin spine with odontodes hypertrophied and tentacles on its distal portion; pectoralfin length variable, usually surpassing a half length of adpressed pelvic fin. Depressed pelvic-fin spine surpassing origin of anal fin. Anal fin short. Caudal-fin margin obliquely truncate, or slightly rounded; lowermost spine slightly longer than superior. Fin-ray formulae: dorsal
I 7
; pectoral
I 6
; pelvic
I 5
; anal
I 3–4
; caudal
I 14
I.

Sexual dimorphism. Males are usually larger than females; largest male and female with 124.8 mm and 79.8 mm SL, respectively. Mature males have middle- to large- sized tentacles on dorsal region and border of snout. Females can have few shorter tentacles, usually two on each side of snout.

Color in alcohol. Background color yellowish-brown to dark-brown; usually with light dots over body; middle-sized on head and trunk, and small on snout. Lips yellowish. Ventral region of head yellowish-brown to anal fin, with light, round or vermiculate dots, usually absent in smaller individuals. Fins yellowish-brown, with dark dots forming three or four stripes or round blotches. Caudal fin with light dots or stripes.

Etymology. The species name,
mullerae
, is in honor of Sonia Fisch-Muller, from the Muséum d'histoire naturelle de la Ville de Genève ( MHNG ), Switzerland , in recognition of her contributions to our understanding of
Ancistrus
species. A patronym.

Distribution.
Ancistrus mullerae
is found in lower Rio Iguaçu basin, upstream from Cataratas do Iguaçu, Southern Brazil (
Fig. 3
).

subSection.paragraph:
The size-free canonical discriminant analysis indicates morphometric differences between species of
Ancistrus
from the Rio Iguaçu (
Fig. 6
). The eigenvalues and the percentage of explanation of each canonical axis (CAN 1 and CAN 2 ) are presented in Table 5 . The first and second canonical axis accounted for 65.6 % and 34.4 %, respectively, of the variation in the original data. The first canonical axis distinguished
A. mullerae
from
A. abilhoai
and
A. agostinhoi
. The characters that contributed singnificantly for discriminating these species were occipital depth, interorbital distance, mandibulary teeth row width, and head length. The second canonical axis discriminated
A. abilhoai
from the others mainly by the caudal peduncle depth, supracleithral width, interdorsal length, and caudal peduncle length.

Regarding geographic distribution of the three new species in the Rio Iguaçu basin,
A. abilhoai
is probably limited to the upper and middle Rio Iguaçu portions, which were isolated from the lower Iguaçu by the Salto Grande fall, currently flooded by the Foz do Areia Reservoir.
Ancistrus agostinhoi
seems to be restricted to the Rio Jordão drainage probably by the falls situated at its mouth, while
A. mullerae
is widespread along the lower Rio Iguaçu portion.

The species described herein can be diagnosed from Amazonian, trans-Andean, and congeners from the Río Orinoco basin by having the base of first anal-fin pterygiophore covered by skin ( i.e. without externally preanal platelet-like element), and by having the maxillary barbel short and not free from the lower lip. From remaining species,
Ancistrus abilhoai
can be further differentiated from
A. agostinhoi
by a narrower caudal peduncle (9.0– 10.9 % of SL, mean= 10.0% vs. 10.6 –12.0%, mean= 11.3 %); from
A. cirrhosus
by a deeper occipital depth ( 18.8–20.6 % of SL vs. 17.9–18.7 %), narrower caudal peduncle ( 31.4–41.8 % of its length vs. 42.8–47.6 %), and higher number of interopercular spines ( 18–25 vs. 12–15 ); from
A. cuiabae
by a higher number of interopercular spines ( 18–25 , mode= 23 vs. 13–20 , mode= 17 ); from
A. multispinis
,
A. mullerae
,
A. pirareta
,
A. piriformis
and
A. taunayi
by a deeper occipital depth ( 18.8–20.6 % of SL vs. 16.2 –18.0%, 15.4– 18.8 %, 13.5–15.4 %, 13.9–16.7 % and 17.3–17.9 %, respectively); and from
A. pirareta
and
A. piriformis
also by a narrower mandibulary row of teeth ( 13.4–15.5 % of HL vs. 15.2–27.7 % and 16.7–21.7 %, respectively) and higher number of interopercular spines ( 18–25 vs.
7–15 and 7–17
, respectively). Additionally, A.

agostinhoi
differs from
A. cirrhosus
by a deeper occipital depth ( 18.8 –22.0% of SL vs. 17.9–18.7 %), longer head length ( 37.8–41.4 % of SL vs. 42.8–47.6 %), and higher number of interopercular spines ( 15–23 vs. 12– 15 ); from
A. cuiabae
by a wider mandibulary teeth row ( 15.8–19.3 % of HL vs. 13.4–15.5 %); from
A. mullerae
by a lower number of dentary teeth ( 38–78 , mode= 50 vs. 51–97 , mode 74 ); from
A. multispinis
and
A. taunayi
by a lower number of interopercular spines ( 15–23 vs. 24–35 and 22–28 , respectively); and from
A. pirareta
and
A. piriformis
by a deeper occipital depth ( 18.8 –22.0% of SL vs. 13.5–15.4 % and 13.9–16.7 %, respectively) and deeper caudal peduncle ( 37.2–48.7 % of its length vs. 27.0– 34.5 % and 28.8–35.7 %, respectively). Furthermore,
A. mullerae
differs from
A. cirrhosus
by a narrower caudal peduncle ( 31.4–42.8 % of its length vs. 42.8–47.6 %) and higher number of dentary teeth ( 51–97 vs. 35–54 ); from
A. cuiabae
by a narrower occipital depth ( 15.4–18.8 % of SL vs. 19.9–24.3 %) and wider mandibulary teeth row ( 16.5 –21.0% of HL vs. 12.2 –15.0%); from
A. multispinis
by a lower number of postopercular plates ( 7–17 , mode= 8 vs. 5– 9 , mode= 8 ); from
A. pirareta
and
A. piriformis
by a deeper caudal peduncle ( 31.4–42.8 %, mean= 37.6 % of its length vs. 27.0– 34.5 %, mean= 30.3 % and 28.8–35.7 %, mean= 31.3 %, respectively); and from
A. taunayi
by the color pattern of body (yellowish-brown with light dots vs. dark-gray with light dots).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. Ordenation of the size-free canonical discriminant analysis on morphometric data of
Ancistrus abilhoai
(square),
A. agostinhoi
(cross) and
A. mullerae
(triangle).

subSection.paragraph:
Besides the aforementioned species,
Fisch-Muller ( 2003 )
also cited in the Rio Paraguai basin the Amazonian
A. hoplogenys (Günther, 1864 )
and
A. dubius Eigenmann & Eigenmann, 1889
. Both species were not identified in the comparative material examined from the Rio Paraguai basin in the present work. They were recorded only in old references, such as
Regan ( 1904 )
, who has cited material of
A. hoplogenys
collected in Descalvados, Mato Grosso State, and
Eigenmann and Kennedy ( 1903 )
, who have cited
A. dubius
, and which can be attributed to misidentifications. Both species are morphologically very similar to
A. cuiabae
, a valid species recently described by
Knaack ( 1999 )
, which could have led to such an interpretation.
Ancistrus dubius
and
A. hoplogenys
are additionally diagnosed from the species described herein of the Rio Iguaçu basin by a wider interorbital distance, narrow mandibulary teeth row, presence of the preanal platelet-like element, premaxillary barbel free from the lower lip, and the pattern of coloration.

Regarding
A. cirrhosus
, the type-species of the genus described from Buenos Aires and Misiones, Argentina , apparently it does not have a preserved holotype .
Isbrücker ( 1980 )
designed a lectotype and six paralectotypes from Buenos Aires, but that procedure was not considered valid by
Fisch-Muller ( 2003 )
. Among the new species, the most similar to
A. cirrhosus
is
A. mullerae
by sharing a shallow body and long tentacles on snout. However,
A. mullerae
has an even narrower caudal peduncle in relation to its length, higher number of dentary teeth, and maxillary barbel not free from the lower lip.

Probably, the real number of
Ancistrus
species is much higher than the number of described species. Exemplifying this is the fact that there is no species described from the upper Rio Paraná basin, a region bearing large rivers with several sub-basins, with a considerably high endemism of fish species (see
Abell et al. 2008
), and with several
Ancistrus
records not identified to the species level. A complete revisionary study of all
Ancistrus
species is necessary for further comprehension of this taxon, including redescriptions of species and designation of lectotypes , for solving problems such as mistaken descriptions and missing or illpreserved types , in addition to descriptions of other probable new species.

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of
Ancistrus
from the Río de La Plata and coastal basins from southern Brazil

paragraph.keyLead:
2 Male
with small pale dots on the head becoming vermiform lines on the trunk; female with very small pale dots all over the body
................................................................. A. claro
(upper Rio Paraguai basin, Chapada dos Guimarães)

3 Mandibulary teeth row 12.2 to 15.0% of HL
..................................................... A. cuiabae
(upper Rio Paraguai basin)

5 Pear-liked body shape; supracleithral width 30.3 to 37.0% of SL
.................... A. piriformis
(lower Río Paraná basin)

- Not pear-liked body shape; supracleithral width 26.3 to 31.3 % of SL
............. A. pirareta
(lower Río Paraguay basin)

6 Orbital diameter 8.3 to 8.7 % of HL
............................................................ A. formoso
(Rio Formoso basin, cave fish)

7 Mandibulary teeth row 13.4 to 15.5 % of HL
.......................... A. abilhoai
n. sp.
(upper and middle Rio Iguaçu basin)

9 Interopercular spines 12 to 22
................................................................... A. mullerae
n. sp.
(lower Rio Iguaçu basin)

10 Postopercular plates 8 to 12 ; plates between anal and caudal 11 to 12
.............. A. taunay
(middle Rio Uruguai basin)
